name: Util
comment: Util class provides static helper functions.

signatures.comment: Check number of items in a Group against a required number

parameters.name: pts
parameters.comment: a Group or an Iterable<PtLike>

parameters.name: minRequired
parameters.comment: minimum number of items required

signatures.comment: Given two arrays of objects, and a function that operate on two objects, return an array. Objects must be of same type.

parameters.name: a
parameters.comment: an array of object, eg `[Group, Group, ...]`

parameters.name: b
parameters.comment: another array of object

parameters.name: op
parameters.comment: a function that takes two parameters (a, b) and returns an object.

signatures.comment: Flatten an array of arrays such as Group[] to a flat Array or Group.

parameters.name: pts
parameters.comment: an array, usually an array of Groups

parameters.name: flattenAsGroup
parameters.comment: a boolean to specify whether the return type should be a Group or Array. Default is `true` which returns a Group.

signatures.comment: A convenient way to step through a range. Same as `for (i=0; i<range; i++)`, except this also stores the resulting return values at each step and return them as an array.
signatures.returns_comment: an array of returned values at each step

parameters.name: fn
parameters.comment: a callback function `fn(index)`. If this function returns a value, it will be stored at each step

parameters.name: range
parameters.comment: a range to step through

signatures.comment: Convert different kinds of parameters (arguments, array, object) into an array of numbers.

parameters.name: args
parameters.comment: can be either a list of numbers, an array, a Pt, or an object with {x,y,z,w} properties

signatures.comment: Check if accessing from a mobile device. Can be useful since some experimental features may not be availble in mobile browsers.
Convert an iterable into an array

parameters.name: it
parameters.comment: an iterable

signatures.comment: A helper function to load data from a url via XMLHttpRequest GET. Since the response passed into callback is a string, if you're loading json data, you may use standard `JSON.parse(response)` to get a JSON object. For csv, try using a javascript csv library like papaparse or vega/datalib.

parameters.name: url
parameters.comment: the request url

parameters.name: callback
parameters.comment: a function to capture the data. It receives two parameters: a `response` as string, and a `success` status as boolean.

signatures.comment: Estimate performance by checking how long it takes to render a frame

parameters.name: avgFrames
parameters.comment: The number of frames used calculate to average

signatures.comment: Get a random integer. This can be useful for selecting a random index in an array.

parameters.name: range
parameters.comment: value range

parameters.name: start
parameters.comment: Optional starting value

signatures.comment: Split an array into chunks of sub-array.

parameters.name: pts
parameters.comment: an array

parameters.name: size
parameters.comment: chunk size, ie, number of items in a chunk

parameters.name: stride
parameters.comment: optional parameter to "walk through" the array in steps

parameters.name: loopBack
parameters.comment: if `true`, always go through the array till the end and loop back to the beginning to complete the segments if needed.

parameters.name: matchSize
parameters.comment: if `true`, all chunks's length must match `size`.

signatures.comment: Create a convenient stepper. This returns a function which you can call repeatedly to step a counter.
signatures.returns_comment: a function which will increment the stepper and return its value at each call.

parameters.name: max
parameters.comment: Maximum of the stepper range. The resulting stepper will return (min to max-1) values.

parameters.name: min
parameters.comment: Minimum of the stepper range. Default is 0.

parameters.name: stride
parameters.comment: Stride of the step. Default is 1.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.comment: An optional callback function `fn( step )`, which will be called each time when stepper function is called.

tags.text: `let counter = stepper(100); let c = counter(); c = counter(); ...`

signatures.comment: Send a warning message based on [`Util.warnLevel`](#link) global setting. This allows you to dynamically set whether minor errors should be thrown or printed in console or muted.

parameters.name: message
parameters.comment: any error or warning message

parameters.name: defaultReturn
parameters.comment: optional return value

signatures.comment: Set a global warning level setting. If no parameter is passed, this will return the current warn-level. See [`Util.warn`](#link).

parameters.name: lv
parameters.comment: a [`WarningType`](#link) option, where "error" will throw an error, "warn" will log in console, and "mute" will ignore the error.

parameters.name: arrays
parameters.comment: an array of arrays
